Dear Roman John Kolodchin:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff to resident ratio
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Description supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
1

checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency staff is not completing 15 minutes checks on youth.
These issues have been addressed with the staff in the past.
Investigation Investigation was assigned on 7/10/2024.
Safehaus is a nonsecure short-term co-ed facility that does not
contract with MDHHS and does not have video cameras inside the
residential home.
Documents reviewed:
Safehaus Bed checks and security monitoring policy – UL0002:
The policy indicated that Safehaus staff will regularly check on
youth during their sleeping period to ensure their safety at all
times. Bed checks are to be made every 15 minutes from 8:30
p.m. (or the time the youth go to bed) to 7:00 a.m. Bed check
notations are to be made on the team log debriefing sheet.
Notations should indicate the exact time the check was made and
the atmosphere at that time. Bed checks are to be conducted at
scheduled staggered intervals according to agency practice.
Electronic Bed Check Log for Safehaus youth. Bed check logs
viewed at the facility on 7/9/24 consistently documented that bed
checks were completed every 15-minutes but lacked variety. For
example, bed check documentation would indicate completion at
12:00 am, 12:15 am, 12:30 am, 12:45 am, etc. rather than varying
intervals.
Analysis The agency is found to be in non-compliance with the licensing
rule. Review of bed check logs documented that the agency failed
to follow the policy as required.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Recreational activities, equipment, and supplies; swimming
Title restriction.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4136
Section (2) Residents shall be provided a variety of indoor and outdoor
Description recreational activities designed to meet the residents’ needs.
2

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff is not providing outdoor recreation to youth.
Investigation Investigation was assigned on 7/10/2024.
Safehaus is a non-secure short-term co-ed facility that does not
contract with MDHHS and does not have video cameras inside the
residential home.
Interviews:
All of the following interviews were completed on 07/09/2024 at
Safehaus unless otherwise noted. An unannounced visit was
conducted to the facility on this date.
Youth A, Youth B and Youth C were interviewed. Youth A
reported she has been at the facility for 3 days and today is her
first time she has been afforded outdoor recreation. Youth B
reported having been at the facility for two days and denied having
any outdoor recreation. Youth C reported not being allowed to go
outside for recreation in the two days she has been at the facility.
Chief administrator (CA) was interviewed and asked for an
update regarding outdoor recreation for youth at the facility. He
advised that since the last unannounced visit the policy had been
updated and changes made to the back yard areas to allow youth
to engage in outdoor recreation. CA also provided photographs
for review that showed staff and youth outside on the back porch
engaging in what appeared to be yoga.
President of Crisis Residential (PCR) was interviewed and she
advised that youth are allowed to engage in outdoor recreation.
After interviewing youth at the facility, PCR was advised that youth
who were interviewed reported having been at the facility for at
least 5 days and denied that they had participated in any outdoor
recreation. PCR advised that the policy allows for discretion of the
staff to take the youth for outdoor recreation based on weather,
behavior and other issues that could occur. PCR was asked if she
had any documentation that would support decisions made by
staff to not allow youth to engage in outdoor recreation based on
weather, behavior or anything else and she responded no.
Staff 2 was interviewed and advised that it was her first day of
employment, thus she was unable to speak regarding schedule or
practices of youth going outside for recreation.
3

Staff 1 was interviewed and she denied that youth are afforded
the opportunity to go outside daily for recreation. She further
added that she believed that the youth could benefit for more
physical activity.
Documents Reviewed:
Safehaus Policy for Outdoor activities - U1099: The policy
indicates that Safehaus Main and Safehaus Too will allow youth to
spend up to 1 hour per day outdoors (weather permitting) in the
backyard of each home and participate in an activity that is
suitable for their age and skill level.
Analysis The agency is found to be in non-compliance with the licensing
rule. Interviews of both staff and youth at the facility resulted in
verification that youth are not receiving outdoor recreation
activities as indicated in the agency policy.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A Corrective Action Plan is required.
